elements.content: We have recently found that organic conductors Ag(DR)2 (DR = 2,5-disubsituted-N,N′-dicyanoquinone diimine; substituent (R) = CH3, Cl, Br, I) irreversibly vary their electrical and magnetic properties by UV irradiation. By selecting the irradiation conditions (wavelengths, temperature, atmosphere, duration), one can accurately control the physical properties from metallic to insulating behavior while retaining their crystal structures. In order to clarify the mechanism of the conductivity change in the case of R = Cl, Br, and I, structure analysis of the irradiated crystals has been carried out. Transmittance electron microscopy and X-ray single crystal structure analysis clarified that the Ag(DCl)2 crystals after 72 h irradiation (375 nm) contained single crystals of nearly three-dimensionally ordered AgCl (0.9 in mole fraction) with varying dimensions (∼1−50 nm). Owing to such a unique hybrid crystal structure, a highly nonlinear current−voltage characteristic unlike any existing electronic devices is observed on irradiated single Ag(DCl)2 crystals.
elements.clean_text: We have recently found that organic conductors Ag(DR)2 (DR = 2,5-disubsituted-N,N'-dicyanoquinone diimine; substituent (R) = CH3, Cl, Br, I) irreversibly vary their electrical and magnetic properties by UV irradiation. By selecting the irradiation conditions (wavelengths, temperature, atmosphere, duration), one can accurately control the physical properties from metallic to insulating behavior while retaining their crystal structures. In order to clarify the mechanism of the conductivity change in the case of R = Cl, Br, and I, structure analysis of the irradiated crystals has been carried out. Transmittance electron microscopy and X-ray single crystal structure analysis clarified that the Ag(DCl)2 crystals after 72 h irradiation (375 nm) contained single crystals of nearly three-dimensionally ordered AgCl (0.9 in mole fraction) with varying dimensions (~1-50 nm). Owing to such a unique hybrid crystal structure, a highly nonlinear current-voltage characteristic unlike any existing electronic devices is observed on irradiated single Ag(DCl)2 crystals.

elements.content: UV-irradiation on the single crystals of an organic conductor caused a partial decomposition to grow insulating nanocrystals in the original crystal. The produced nanocrystals were highly oriented to give Bragg reflections, and the lattice of the organic conductor was also retained. Such hybrid crystals exhibited non-ohmic current−voltage properties, which are different from any existing semiconducting devices such as varistors and diodes.
elements.clean_text: UV-irradiation on the single crystals of an organic conductor caused a partial decomposition to grow insulating nanocrystals in the original crystal. The produced nanocrystals were highly oriented to give Bragg reflections, and the lattice of the organic conductor was also retained. Such hybrid crystals exhibited non-ohmic current-voltage properties, which are different from any existing semiconducting devices such as varistors and diodes.

elements.content: Nowadays, various types of combined structures composed of different materials attract growing interest for potential applications to catalysis, electronic and magnetic materials. As junction structures play an important role in electronic devices, advanced functionalities often require a combination of totally different materials with a well-defined interface of an atomic or molecular scale. To realize such structures, the strategies using chemical reactions turned out to be powerful methods. For example, using photochemical reactions to produce a hybrid material, one can modify the electronic and the magnetic properties of organic conductors, Ag(DR)2 (Figure ; R = CH3, Cl, Br, I), by UV−vis light irradiation. The chloride derivative Ag(DCl)2 originally, that is, before irradiation, exhibits metallic properties at T ≥ 70 K. The conduction occurs through the π-band of DCl radical species stacking along the crystallographic c-axis (so-called one-dimensional (1D) metal). In such 1D metals, one can switch their conducting and magnetic properties by varying temperature, in sharp contrast with the naturally occurring elemental metals. However, our recent work demonstrated that one could also change its physical properties at room temperature (RT) from paramagnetic/metallic to diamagnetic/insulating states in an irreversible and well-controlled way simply by UV−vis irradiation such as a photolithographic technique. Using this method, we actually made a junction-structure required for electronic device function such as diodes. Various analysis indicated that the change in physical properties originates from the decomposition of Ag(DCl)2 to produce AgCl in the sample. However, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) demonstrated that the samples retained their original well-defined crystalline shape after irradiation. This means that all or most of the AgCl crystals produced within the bulk, not on the surface. What is more, a preliminary X-ray structural analysis gave identical crystal structures on the pristine and on the irradiated single crystals, which indicated that a substantial part of the sample retained its original lattice structure after irradiation, in spite of the partial decomposition to AgCl. Consistently, the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of Ag(DCl)2 remained apparently unchanged after irradiation. Naturally, the following questions occurred to us: (1) why did the XRD pattern/crystal structure of Ag(DCl)2 NOT change after irradiation? and (2) why and how did AgCl selectively occur in the bulk rather than on the surface of Ag(DCl)2? We have another motivation in this study. Since the two kinds of the material are totally different from each other in chemical, physical, and structural properties, such direct growth of crystal(s)-in-a-crystal is a very rare case as far as we know. The resultant material should have well-defined interfaces between Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl, which is an important structural feature for device functions. For example, the single crystal of Ag(DCl)2 could be transformed to a metal−insulator−semiconductor structure, which can serve as a tunneling diode or a field-effect transistor, depending on the thickness and arrangement of the AgCl phase. In the previous work, we had no information how they actually existed in the irradiated part of Ag(DCl)2. Thus, detailed X-ray structural analyses have been carried out and the whole structure of irradiated samples has now been established. In this paper, we report the structural analysis on a photochemical crystal growth in another single crystal with totally different chemical, physical, and structural properties from each other.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, various types of combined structures composed of different materials attract growing interest for potential applications to catalysis, electronic and magnetic materials. As junction structures play an important role in electronic devices, advanced functionalities often require a combination of totally different materials with a well-defined interface of an atomic or molecular scale. To realize such structures, the strategies using chemical reactions turned out to be powerful methods. For example, using photochemical reactions to produce a hybrid material, one can modify the electronic and the magnetic properties of organic conductors, Ag(DR)2 (Figure ; R = CH3, Cl, Br, I), by UV-vis light irradiation. The chloride derivative Ag(DCl)2 originally, that is, before irradiation, exhibits metallic properties at T ≥ 70 K. The conduction occurs through the π-band of DCl radical species stacking along the crystallographic c-axis (so-called one-dimensional (1D) metal). In such 1D metals, one can switch their conducting and magnetic properties by varying temperature, in sharp contrast with the naturally occurring elemental metals. However, our recent work demonstrated that one could also change its physical properties at room temperature (RT) from paramagnetic/metallic to diamagnetic/insulating states in an irreversible and well-controlled way simply by UV-vis irradiation such as a photolithographic technique. Using this method, we actually made a junction-structure required for electronic device function such as diodes. Various analysis indicated that the change in physical properties originates from the decomposition of Ag(DCl)2 to produce AgCl in the sample. However, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) demonstrated that the samples retained their original well-defined crystalline shape after irradiation. This means that all or most of the AgCl crystals produced within the bulk, not on the surface. What is more, a preliminary X-ray structural analysis gave identical crystal structures on the pristine and on the irradiated single crystals, which indicated that a substantial part of the sample retained its original lattice structure after irradiation, in spite of the partial decomposition to AgCl. Consistently, the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of Ag(DCl)2 remained apparently unchanged after irradiation. Naturally, the following questions occurred to us: (1) why did the XRD pattern/crystal structure of Ag(DCl)2 NOT change after irradiation? and (2) why and how did AgCl selectively occur in the bulk rather than on the surface of Ag(DCl)2? We have another motivation in this study. Since the two kinds of the material are totally different from each other in chemical, physical, and structural properties, such direct growth of crystal(s)-in-a-crystal is a very rare case as far as we know. The resultant material should have well-defined interfaces between Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl, which is an important structural feature for device functions. For example, the single crystal of Ag(DCl)2 could be transformed to a metal-insulator-semiconductor structure, which can serve as a tunneling diode or a field-effect transistor, depending on the thickness and arrangement of the AgCl phase. In the previous work, we had no information how they actually existed in the irradiated part of Ag(DCl)2. Thus, detailed X-ray structural analyses have been carried out and the whole structure of irradiated samples has now been established. In this paper, we report the structural analysis on a photochemical crystal growth in another single crystal with totally different chemical, physical, and structural properties from each other.

elements.content: Molecular structure of DR (upper left) and crystal structure of Ag(DCl)2: stacking of DR (upper right) and a view down on the ab-plane (lower), Ag; pink, C; gray, H; white, N; pale blue, Cl; green. All Ag(DR)2 are isostructural.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structure of DR (upper left) and crystal structure of Ag(DCl)2: stacking of DR (upper right) and a view down on the ab-plane (lower), Ag; pink, C; gray, H; white, N; pale blue, Cl; green. All Ag(DR)2 are isostructural.

elements.content: Single crystals of Ag(DCl)2 were prepared according to the literature. UV−vis irradiation was carried out using a UV laser (375 ± 5 nm, 20 mW, NEOARK TC-20-3720-15) with a light guide (a multimode fiber; 1-m length) of adjustable focus, NA, and size of the beam spot under high vacuum (∼5 × 10−7 Pa) atmosphere at room temperature (∼20 °C). The dependence of irradiation effects on wavelengths, intensity, atmosphere and temperature was previously examined in detail, and no differences were observed except for the time of irradiation required.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Single crystals of Ag(DCl)2 were prepared according to the literature. UV-vis irradiation was carried out using a UV laser (375 ± 5 nm, 20 mW, NEOARK TC-20-3720-15) with a light guide (a multimode fiber; 1-m length) of adjustable focus, NA, and size of the beam spot under high vacuum (~5 × 10-7 Pa) atmosphere at room temperature (~20 °C). The dependence of irradiation effects on wavelengths, intensity, atmosphere and temperature was previously examined in detail, and no differences were observed except for the time of irradiation required.

elements.content: X-ray oscillation photographs (ω-scan) were collected using R-AXIS RAPID-SF (Rigaku) at RT (300 K) and/or at low temperature (200 and/or 100 K) for both of the irradiated and the pristine samples. Each X-ray oscillation photograph was taken with a total exposure of 5−60 min and oscillation angle of 6−10 deg. In order to check crystal quality and sample-dependence of irradiation effects, 23 crystals were examined by X-ray oscillation photographs to select the most appropriate sample for subsequent structural analysis. Structure solution, refinement, and all subsequent calculations were carried out using the standard crystallographic software packages attached to the diffractometer (RAPID, CrystalStructure, CRYSTALS). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Annealing of the irradiated crystals was carried out at 300 K and from 313 to 433 K with every 10 K for 5 min at each temperature. Further details of X-ray structural study are given in the following CIF files, which are available directly from the author (tnaito@sci.hokudai.ac.jp) or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif): pristine Ag(DCl)2 (300 K; CCDC 791876, 100 K; CCDC 791875) and irradiated Ag(DCl)2 (100 K; CCDC 791877).

Each X-ray oscillation photograph was taken with a total exposure of 5-60 min and oscillation angle of 6-10 deg. In order to check crystal quality and sample-dependence of irradiation effects, 23 crystals were examined by X-ray oscillation photographs to select the most appropriate sample for subsequent structural analysis. Structure solution, refinement, and all subsequent calculations were carried out using the standard crystallographic software packages attached to the diffractometer (RAPID, CrystalStructure, CRYSTALS). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Annealing of the irradiated crystals was carried out at 300 K and from 313 to 433 K with every 10 K for 5 min at each temperature. Further details of X-ray structural study are given in the following CIF files, which are available directly from the author (tnaito@sci.hokudai.ac.jp) or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif): pristine Ag(DCl)2 (300 K; CCDC 791876, 100 K; CCDC 791875) and irradiated Ag(DCl)2 (100 K; CCDC 791877).

elements.content: Transmittance electron microprobe (TEM) was carried out using a JEOL JEM-2000ES (acceleration voltage 200 kV) attached with energy dispersion X-ray microanalyzer (EDX). In the observation, the microcrystalline sample was mounted on a Cu mesh plate coated with collodion film (Nisshin EM Co., Ltd.).
elements.clean_text: Transmittance electron microprobe (TEM) was carried out using a JEOL JEM-2000ES (acceleration voltage 200 kV) attached with energy dispersion X-ray microanalyzer (EDX). In the observation, the microcrystalline sample was mounted on a Cu mesh plate coated with collodion film (Nisshin EM Co., Ltd.).

elements.content: The current−voltage (I−V) characteristics were measured by a two-probe method between −5 V and +5 V at 298 K in a homemade closed (i.e., dark) cryostat. The electrical contacts were made by gold wires (20 μmϕ) and gold paste (Tokuriki, No. 8560). The current/voltage direction is in the longitudinal direction of the needle-shaped crystals, which coincides with the conducting direction (the crystallographic c-axis) of Ag(DCl)2. The I−V characteristic measurements were carried out first on the pristine samples (nonirradiated single crystals) of Ag(DCl)2 to confirm the initial I−V curves. Then UV light was irradiated on the samples, which were on the sample stage for electrical measurements with the electrical leads attached, and after irradiation their I−V curves were measured again. The I−V properties of the same single crystals were compared between their pristine states and the states after irradiation (4 h). Several samples were studied in order to check any sample-dependence and artifacts.
elements.clean_text: The current-voltage (I-V) characteristics were measured by a two-probe method between -5 V and +5 V at 298 K in a homemade closed (i.e., dark) cryostat. The electrical contacts were made by gold wires (20 μmϕ) and gold paste (Tokuriki, No. 8560). The current/voltage direction is in the longitudinal direction of the needle-shaped crystals, which coincides with the conducting direction (the crystallographic c-axis) of Ag(DCl)2. The I-V characteristic measurements were carried out first on the pristine samples (nonirradiated single crystals) of Ag(DCl)2 to confirm the initial I-V curves. Then UV light was irradiated on the samples, which were on the sample stage for electrical measurements with the electrical leads attached, and after irradiation their I-V curves were measured again. The I-V properties of the same single crystals were compared between their pristine states and the states after irradiation (4 h). Several samples were studied in order to check any sample-dependence and artifacts.

elements.content: Table shows a summary of the crystal structure determination for the pristine and the irradiated Ag(DCl)2. The molecular and crystal structures of the pristine Ag(DCl)2 quantitatively agreed with those previously reported. There is almost no difference in the crystal/molecular structures between the pristine and the irradiated samples; all the inter- and intramolecular distances and angles agree with each other within 1%; changes of selected bond lengths are shown in Table . The bond distances are identical within experimental errors. All the X-ray oscillation photographs of the irradiated samples contained additional spots (“peaks X”; Figure ), which could not be assigned to Ag(DCl)2. The “peaks X” did not disappear after washing the sample in acetone, brushing the sample, or scrubbing the sample with a fine glass capillary, which suggested that their origin was not (solely) on the surface. These observations are consistent with the previous results (SEM); their appearances did not change at all after irradiation.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Table  shows a summary of the crystal structure determination for the pristine and the irradiated Ag(DCl)2. The molecular and crystal structures of the pristine Ag(DCl)2 quantitatively agreed with those previously reported. There is almost no difference in the crystal/molecular structures between the pristine and the irradiated samples; all the inter- and intramolecular distances and angles agree with each other within 1%; changes of selected bond lengths are shown in Table . The bond distances are identical within experimental errors. All the X-ray oscillation photographs of the irradiated samples contained additional spots ("peaks X"; Figure ), which could not be assigned to Ag(DCl)2. The "peaks X" did not disappear after washing the sample in acetone, brushing the sample, or scrubbing the sample with a fine glass capillary, which suggested that their origin was not (solely) on the surface. These observations are consistent with the previous results (SEM); their appearances did not change at all after irradiation.

elements.content: Close view of an X-ray oscillation photograph of Ag(DCl)2 crystal taken at 100 K after UV-irradiation for 72 h. The inset shows a 3D image of a peak profile. Squares indicate the Bragg reflections due to Ag(DCl)2 lattice, which correspond to the sharper (higher) peak in the inset. The broader peaks correspond to the AgCl crystals, all of which are highly oriented in a 3D way to give Bragg reflections instead of Debye rings.
elements.clean_text: 2  Close view of an X-ray oscillation photograph of Ag(DCl)2 crystal taken at 100 K after UV-irradiation for 72 h. The inset shows a 3D image of a peak profile. Squares indicate the Bragg reflections due to Ag(DCl)2 lattice, which correspond to the sharper (higher) peak in the inset. The broader peaks correspond to the AgCl crystals, all of which are highly oriented in a 3D way to give Bragg reflections instead of Debye rings.

Annealing of the crystals at 313−433 K clearly divided the reflections in two classes in terms of its effects. Annealing below ∼373 K did not change the X-ray oscillation photographs significantly. However, annealing above ∼373 K suddenly and markedly increased the “peaks X” in intensity (Figure ). At the same time, the diffraction peaks of Ag(DCl)2 decreased in accordance with the increase of the “peaks X”. After annealing at 433 K, the reflections due to the Ag(DCl)2 lattice almost completely disappeared, and the diffraction pattern on the X-ray oscillation photographs totally changed. This means that some structural drastic change occurred at ∼373 K, and that not only UV-irradiation but also annealing (heating above ∼373 K) brought about the decomposition of Ag(DCl)2. An important difference lies in that it was far more effective, but at the same time far more difficult to control, to transform Ag(DCl)2 into AgCl by heating than by UV-irradiation. Both of the facts agree with the previous results in a quantitative way (temperature-dependent powder XRD simultaneously measured with differential scanning calorimetry (XRD-DSC)). Using a sample irradiated for 72 h followed by annealing at 433 K, crystal structural analysis of the observed diffraction pattern of “peaks X” unambiguously indicated that it should be assigned to the AgCl lattice (α = β = γ = 90°, a = 5.53(2) Å), which is consistent with previous results (powder XRD, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), IR spectra and DSC).
elements.clean_text: Annealing of the crystals at 313-433 K clearly divided the reflections in two classes in terms of its effects. Annealing below ~373 K did not change the X-ray oscillation photographs significantly. However, annealing above ~373 K suddenly and markedly increased the "peaks X" in intensity (Figure ). At the same time, the diffraction peaks of Ag(DCl)2 decreased in accordance with the increase of the "peaks X". After annealing at 433 K, the reflections due to the Ag(DCl)2 lattice almost completely disappeared, and the diffraction pattern on the X-ray oscillation photographs totally changed. This means that some structural drastic change occurred at ~373 K, and that not only UV-irradiation but also annealing (heating above ~373 K) brought about the decomposition of Ag(DCl)2. An important difference lies in that it was far more effective, but at the same time far more difficult to control, to transform Ag(DCl)2 into AgCl by heating than by UV-irradiation. Both of the facts agree with the previous results in a quantitative way (temperature-dependent powder XRD simultaneously measured with differential scanning calorimetry (XRD-DSC)). Using a sample irradiated for 72 h followed by annealing at 433 K, crystal structural analysis of the observed diffraction pattern of "peaks X" unambiguously indicated that it should be assigned to the AgCl lattice (α = β = γ = 90°, a = 5.53(2) Å), which is consistent with previous results (powder XRD, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), IR spectra and DSC).

Ellipses (“peaks X”) and squares (Ag(DCl)2) indicate reflections showing contrasting effects of annealing.

elements.content: On the other hand, quantitative analysis of the structure factors observed at 100 K enabled us to estimate the mole and the volume fractions of AgCl in an irradiated crystal of Ag(DCl)2. After UV-irradiation of 72 h, a single crystal of Ag(DCl)2 contained crystalline AgCl with a mole fraction of 0.90 and a volume fraction of 0.45. In spite of such a significant amount of AgCl produced by decomposition of Ag(DCl)2, the crystal structures of both Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl are clearly solved on the irradiated “single crystal”, and one could observe almost no differences in the lattice and molecular structure of Ag(DCl)2 after irradiation. The mole fractions of Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl in the irradiated crystals can explain the previously observed magnetic susceptibilities of the irradiated samples in a quantitative way.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, quantitative analysis of the structure factors observed at 100 K enabled us to estimate the mole and the volume fractions of AgCl in an irradiated crystal of Ag(DCl)2. After UV-irradiation of 72 h, a single crystal of Ag(DCl)2 contained crystalline AgCl with a mole fraction of 0.90 and a volume fraction of 0.45. In spite of such a significant amount of AgCl produced by decomposition of Ag(DCl)2, the crystal structures of both Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl are clearly solved on the irradiated "single crystal", and one could observe almost no differences in the lattice and molecular structure of Ag(DCl)2 after irradiation. The mole fractions of Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl in the irradiated crystals can explain the previously observed magnetic susceptibilities of the irradiated samples in a quantitative way.

elements.content: Now let us discuss the question (1) posed in the . The powder XRD pattern of Ag(DCl)2 hardly changed after UV-irradiation. This is explained as follows. Even in the practically diamagnetic AgCl/Ag(DCl)2 mixed crystalline samples, which contain 0.90 (0.45) of AgCl in mole (volume) fraction, the X-ray diffraction intensities from AgCl crystalline parts were 0.3−1% of those of most intense reflections. This is why the produced AgCl did not affect the profile of the powder patterns in an apparent way. Then, why did the crystal structure of Ag(DCl)2 not change after irradiation? The answer is closely related to the question (2) and is discussed below.
elements.clean_text: Now let us discuss the question (1) posed in the . The powder XRD pattern of Ag(DCl)2 hardly changed after UV-irradiation. This is explained as follows. Even in the practically diamagnetic AgCl/Ag(DCl)2 mixed crystalline samples, which contain 0.90 (0.45) of AgCl in mole (volume) fraction, the X-ray diffraction intensities from AgCl crystalline parts were 0.3-1% of those of most intense reflections. This is why the produced AgCl did not affect the profile of the powder patterns in an apparent way. Then, why did the crystal structure of Ag(DCl)2 not change after irradiation? The answer is closely related to the question (2) and is discussed below.

elements.content: The X-ray structural analysis suggests that the crystals of AgCl are widely distributed in the irradiated part rather than it forming a single domain. In the meantime, the X-ray reflections due to the AgCl lattice formed slightly broad but clear spots instead of Debye rings, which proved that the nanocrystals should be nearly ordered in a three-dimensional (3D) way in the Ag(DCl)2 lattice. As is generally the case, an epitaxial growth should occur when a new phase separates from a single crystalline phase. In other words, the original Ag(DCl)2 lattice is considered to have served as a template to keep the structural coherence among distant crystals of AgCl, which align them all in a particular orientation with controlling their growth. The conclusion from the structural study is supported by TEM as shown in Figure . A series of TEM photographs showed us a number of AgCl cubic nanocrystals (Ag/Cl = 49.65:50.35 in atom% from EDX) distributed in/on the Ag(DCl)2 needle-shaped crystals irradiated for 72 h. Their dimensions vary from ≤1 nm to ∼50 nm, and many of the crystals occur around 15 nm in size. The lattice images of AgCl and Ag(DCl)2 were also found in some of the photographs, which is consistent with the X-ray structural study. Most of the AgCl crystals are incorporated in the bulk of Ag(DCl)2 crystals, instead of growing on the surface. Detailed examination clarified that at the initial stage of irradiation (≤50−80 h, depending on the thickness of the crystals) the produced AgCl crystals started to grow in the bulk of Ag(DCl)2 and gradually appeared on the surface when their concentration in the bulk of Ag(DCl)2 became high. Irrespective of irradiation conditions, we did not observe any large (≫50 nm) single crystal of AgCl until complete decomposition of Ag(DCl)2.
elements.clean_text: The X-ray structural analysis suggests that the crystals of AgCl are widely distributed in the irradiated part rather than it forming a single domain. In the meantime, the X-ray reflections due to the AgCl lattice formed slightly broad but clear spots instead of Debye rings, which proved that the nanocrystals should be nearly ordered in a three-dimensional (3D) way in the Ag(DCl)2 lattice. As is generally the case, an epitaxial growth should occur when a new phase separates from a single crystalline phase. In other words, the original Ag(DCl)2 lattice is considered to have served as a template to keep the structural coherence among distant crystals of AgCl, which align them all in a particular orientation with controlling their growth. The conclusion from the structural study is supported by TEM as shown in Figure . A series of TEM photographs showed us a number of AgCl cubic nanocrystals (Ag/Cl = 49.65:50.35 in atom% from EDX) distributed in/on the Ag(DCl)2 needle-shaped crystals irradiated for 72 h. Their dimensions vary from ≤1 nm to ~50 nm, and many of the crystals occur around 15 nm in size. The lattice images of AgCl and Ag(DCl)2  were also found in some of the photographs, which is consistent with the X-ray structural study. Most of the AgCl crystals are incorporated in the bulk of Ag(DCl)2 crystals, instead of growing on the surface. Detailed examination clarified that at the initial stage of irradiation (≤50-80 h, depending on the thickness of the crystals) the produced AgCl crystals started to grow in the bulk of Ag(DCl)2 and gradually appeared on the surface when their concentration in the bulk of Ag(DCl)2 became high. Irrespective of irradiation conditions, we did not observe any large (≫50 nm) single crystal of AgCl until complete decomposition of Ag(DCl)2.

elements.content: TEM photographs of UV-irradiated (72 h) Ag(DCl)2 crystal; (a) overview of an end of a needle-shaped crystal, and (b) close view of a cubic crystal of AgCl in Ag(DCl)2.
elements.clean_text: 4  TEM photographs of UV-irradiated (72 h) Ag(DCl)2 crystal; (a) overview of an end of a needle-shaped crystal, and (b) close view of a cubic crystal of AgCl in Ag(DCl)2.

elements.content: Let us discuss here question (2) in the . The photochemically produced AgCl nanocrystals occurred in the bulk instead of on the surface of Ag(DCl)2 crystals. This result might be explained if we consider that interaction between Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl lattices should stabilize the mixed phase (i.e., maximum contact between Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl) than otherwise (a phase-separation-like state). The observed lattice parameter (5.53(2) Å) suggested a deviation from that of isolated AgCl single crystals (5.5463(2) Å), which suggests the interaction. Furthermore, thus produced AgR (R = Cl, Br, I) in Ag(DR)2 exhibited exothermic peaks in DSC at significantly (∼ 80 K) lower temperatures than their melting points in the pure states. Since the lattice of Ag(DCl)2 is composed of 3D infinite covalent/coordination bond network -Ag-DCl-Ag- in addition to the “metallic bonds” among the DCl radical anions, its deformation should be energetically unfavorable, and thus the crystal structure practically remained unchanged after irradiation. Because of such energetic conditions (maximum contact between AgCl and Ag(DCl)2 and minimum deformation of the Ag(DCl)2 lattice), the produced AgCl crystals should be incorporated and remain small such as nanocrystals.
elements.clean_text: Let us discuss here question (2) in the . The photochemically produced AgCl nanocrystals occurred in the bulk instead of on the surface of Ag(DCl)2 crystals. This result might be explained if we consider that interaction between Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl lattices should stabilize the mixed phase (i.e., maximum contact between Ag(DCl)2 and AgCl) than otherwise (a phase-separation-like state). The observed lattice parameter (5.53(2) Å) suggested a deviation from that of isolated AgCl single crystals (5.5463(2) Å), which suggests the interaction. Furthermore, thus produced AgR (R = Cl, Br, I) in Ag(DR)2 exhibited exothermic peaks in DSC at significantly (~ 80 K) lower temperatures than their melting points in the pure states. Since the lattice of Ag(DCl)2 is composed of 3D infinite covalent/coordination bond network -Ag-DCl-Ag- in addition to the "metallic bonds" among the DCl radical anions, its deformation should be energetically unfavorable, and thus the crystal structure practically remained unchanged after irradiation. Because of such energetic conditions (maximum contact between AgCl and Ag(DCl)2 and minimum deformation of the Ag(DCl)2 lattice), the produced AgCl crystals should be incorporated and remain small such as nanocrystals.

elements.content: Such an apparently “single crystal” composed of two different materials possesses well-defined interfaces/grain boundaries, which is interesting in terms of electronic device action. In fact, the microstructure shown in Figure reminds us of polycrystalline devices such as varistors (variable resistors) of ceramics. In this case, the AgCl crystals serve as a kind of dopant, which fragment the 1D conduction pathways composed of the DCl radical anions, though the AgCl crystals do not change the number of carriers (unpaired electrons) on DCl. Only the decomposition of the DCl radical anions results in the decrease of carriers. The 1D conductors are generally sensitive to such lattice defects and readily vary their electrical and magnetic properties with such chemical perturbation. Most of the AgCl crystals produced in Ag(DCl)2 are larger than 1 nm, and thus tunneling current through them is negligible. This means that most of the AgCl crystals should serve as insulating barriers to block the conduction pathway. If an appropriate amount of AgCl crystals is incorporated, the Ag(DCl)2 crystals might exhibit non-ohmic electrical behavior.
elements.clean_text: Such an apparently "single crystal" composed of two different materials possesses well-defined interfaces/grain boundaries, which is interesting in terms of electronic device action. In fact, the microstructure shown in Figure  reminds us of polycrystalline devices such as varistors (variable resistors) of ceramics. In this case, the AgCl crystals serve as a kind of dopant, which fragment the 1D conduction pathways composed of the DCl radical anions, though the AgCl crystals do not change the number of carriers (unpaired electrons) on DCl. Only the decomposition of the DCl radical anions results in the decrease of carriers. The 1D conductors are generally sensitive to such lattice defects and readily vary their electrical and magnetic properties with such chemical perturbation. Most of the AgCl crystals produced in Ag(DCl)2 are larger than 1 nm, and thus tunneling current through them is negligible. This means that most of the AgCl crystals should serve as insulating barriers to block the conduction pathway. If an appropriate amount of AgCl crystals is incorporated, the Ag(DCl)2 crystals might exhibit non-ohmic electrical behavior.

elements.content: Actually, UV-irradiation of a whole single crystal of Ag(DCl)2 produced unusual electrical behavior. Figure shows typical I−V characteristics observed for the Ag(DCl)2 “single crystals” containing AgCl of 0.487 in mole fraction (0.0098 in volume fraction), which was determined from X-ray structural analysis. There are two unusual features in the electrical behavior in Figure .

There are two unusual features in the electrical behavior in Figure .

elements.content: I−V curves of wholly irradiated Ag(DCl)2 crystals with observed (squares) and calculated (eq ; solid line) behavior. Panels a−c show typical types of behavior observed for different crystalline samples. All of them contain the same total amount of AgCl single crystals (0.487 in mole fraction; 0.0098 in volume fraction).
elements.clean_text: 5   I-V curves of wholly irradiated Ag(DCl)2 crystals with observed (squares) and calculated (eq ; solid line) behavior. Panels a-c show typical types of behavior observed for different crystalline samples. All of them contain the same total amount of AgCl single crystals (0.487 in mole fraction; 0.0098 in volume fraction).

elements.content: First, all of the I−V characteristics are highly reproducible but are different from either the varistors’ or diodes’ characteristics. Some are asymmetric against applied voltage, which is evidently different from varistors’ characteristics and is rather similar to diodes’ behavior. On the other hand, the Ag(DCl)2/AgCl systems cannot have diode-type junction-structures, as long as the whole crystals are irradiated homogeneously. Rather, they should have varistor-like structures on the bases of the results mentioned above. The structure of a varistor is characterized with many insulating grain-boundaries separating conducting voltage-dependent resistor (VDR) grains, while that of a diode is characterized with a single clear-cut interface separating two regions of different conducting properties. Generally, the former is a polycrystalline material without anisotropy (i.e., without 3D ordering or orientation of microcrystals), while the latter is a doped single crystalline material with a clear anisotropy in conduction. The structural feature of the Ag(DCl)2/AgCl crystalline system is different from either of them. This can be related to the observed unique behavior, in addition to the inherent strong 1D anisotropy in conduction of the mother material Ag(DCl)2.
elements.clean_text: First, all of the I-V characteristics are highly reproducible but are different from either the varistors' or diodes' characteristics. Some are asymmetric against applied voltage, which is evidently different from varistors' characteristics and is rather similar to diodes' behavior. On the other hand, the Ag(DCl)2/AgCl systems cannot have diode-type junction-structures, as long as the whole crystals are irradiated homogeneously. Rather, they should have varistor-like structures on the bases of the results mentioned above. The structure of a varistor is characterized with many insulating grain-boundaries separating conducting voltage-dependent resistor (VDR) grains, while that of a diode is characterized with a single clear-cut interface separating two regions of different conducting properties. Generally, the former is a polycrystalline material without anisotropy (i.e., without 3D ordering or orientation of microcrystals), while the latter is a doped single crystalline material with a clear anisotropy in conduction. The structural feature of the Ag(DCl)2/AgCl crystalline system is different from either of them. This can be related to the observed unique behavior, in addition to the inherent strong 1D anisotropy in conduction of the mother material Ag(DCl)2.

elements.content: Second, in spite of containing the same amount of the AgCl crystals, the I−V characteristics differ from each other. This can be explained when we consider that the distribution, the number, and the dimensions of the AgCl crystals should differ from sample to sample, and that such conditions should sensitively affect the resultant I−V properties. One can analyze the I−V curves using the following model (eq ), which can be generally applied to the electrical behavior of VDR systems based on the Schottky diode picture of the potential barriers. J = J 0 ( e ϕ k B T ) { exp ( e V p k B T ) − 1 } where J, J 0, ϕ, and p are the current through the potential barrier, a constant which can be a function of temperature, the potential barrier height, and the number of barrier per unit length in the sample, respectively. The remaining parameters e, k B, and T are the elementary electric charge (1.60 × 10−19 [C]), the Boltzmann constant (1.38 × 10−23 [J K−1]), and the measurement temperature (298 K), respectively. The obtained parameters are summarized in Table . Although the detailed mechanism of nonlinear I−V characteristic of VDR systems still remains to be clarified, the results in Table indicate that the potential barrier height ϕ should significantly depend on details of the structure. The obtained values of p are approximately consistent with the grain sizes ((30−50)−1 mm ∼20−30 μm on average) observed by TEM. Because of the well-defined crystalline structure and the 1D conduction property, the Ag(DCl)2/AgCl system might provide a more simplified model sample for study of VDR mechanism, which is important for both basic and applied research in device technology but has remained elusive for nearly 80 years.

One can analyze the I-V curves using the following model (eq ), which can be generally applied to the electrical behavior of VDR systems based on the Schottky diode picture of the potential barriers. 1  J =   J   0    (    e ϕ     k   B   T    )   {  exp  (    e V   p   k   B   T    )  - 1  }   where J, J 0, ϕ, and p are the current through the potential barrier, a constant which can be a function of temperature, the potential barrier height, and the number of barrier per unit length in the sample, respectively. The remaining parameters e, k B, and T are the elementary electric charge (1.60 × 10-19 [C]), the Boltzmann constant (1.38 × 10-23 [J K-1]), and the measurement temperature (298 K), respectively. The obtained parameters are summarized in Table . Although the detailed mechanism of nonlinear I-V characteristic of VDR systems still remains to be clarified, the results in Table  indicate that the potential barrier height ϕ should significantly depend on details of the structure. The obtained values of p are approximately consistent with the grain sizes ((30-50)-1 mm ~20-30 μm on average) observed by TEM. Because of the well-defined crystalline structure and the 1D conduction property, the Ag(DCl)2/AgCl system might provide a more simplified model sample for study of VDR mechanism, which is important for both basic and applied research in device technology but has remained elusive for nearly 80 years.

In this paper, we have shown that one could grow nanocrystals directly in a different crystalline material as a way of making nanoscale-junction- or hybrid-crystalline-structures. The produced nanocrystals varied in size; however, the total amount of the crystals could be controlled, and their orientations were ordered in a 3D way. One of the possible applications is to transform the molecular conductors into VDR systems. Because the I−V characteristics are sensitive to details of the microstructure, the next goal is to elucidate which structural factors to determine the I−V characteristics and how to control them.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this paper, we have shown that one could grow nanocrystals directly in a different crystalline material as a way of making nanoscale-junction- or hybrid-crystalline-structures. The produced nanocrystals varied in size; however, the total amount of the crystals could be controlled, and their orientations were ordered in a 3D way. One of the possible applications is to transform the molecular conductors into VDR systems. Because the I-V characteristics are sensitive to details of the microstructure, the next goal is to elucidate which structural factors to determine the I-V characteristics and how to control them.

elements.content: By adjusting the duration of irradiation, the ratio of the original (Ag(DCl)2) and the decomposed (AgCl) materials in an apparently single crystal can be arbitrarily controlled with retaining the original lattice structure of Ag(DCl)2.

References

By adjusting the duration of irradiation, the ratio of the original (Ag(DCl)2) and the decomposed (AgCl) materials in an apparently single crystal can be arbitrarily controlled with retaining the original lattice structure of Ag(DCl)2.

elements.content:
It exhibits a metal-to-insulator transition at 70 K. The Ag+ ions are irrelevant to the electrical and the magnetic properties of these salts, because they do not have unpaired electrons.

We confirmed that the results agreed qualitatively; that is, nonohmic behavior was reproducibly observed using either of a four-probe method or a two-probe method. However, the data were clearer when we attached only the two leads at both ends of a sample, probably because the part of the sample to be irradiated could be exposed to light as homogeneously as possible. The voltage-dependent resistor (VDR) device behavior is known to be not affected by the electrode configuration or electrode composition.

It exhibits a metal-to-insulator transition at 70 K. The Ag+ ions are irrelevant to the electrical and the magnetic properties of these salts, because they do not have unpaired electrons.

We confirmed that the results agreed qualitatively; that is, nonohmic behavior was reproducibly observed using either of a four-probe method or a two-probe method. However, the data were clearer when we attached only the two leads at both ends of a sample, probably because the part of the sample to be irradiated could be exposed to light as homogeneously as possible. The voltage-dependent resistor (VDR) device behavior is known to be not affected by the electrode configuration or electrode composition.

cln_elements.content: Molecular structure of DR (upper left) and crystal structure of Ag(DCl)2: stacking of DR (upper right) and a view down on the ab-plane (lower), Ag; pink, C; gray, H; white, N; pale blue, Cl; green. All Ag(DR)2 are isostructural.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structure of DR (upper left) and crystal structure of Ag(DCl)2: stacking of DR (upper right) and a view down on the ab-plane (lower), Ag; pink, C; gray, H; white, N; pale blue, Cl; green. All Ag(DR)2 are isostructural.

cln_elements.content: Close view of an X-ray oscillation photograph of Ag(DCl)2 crystal taken at 100 K after UV-irradiation for 72 h. The inset shows a 3D image of a peak profile. Squares indicate the Bragg reflections due to Ag(DCl)2 lattice, which correspond to the sharper (higher) peak in the inset. The broader peaks correspond to the AgCl crystals, all of which are highly oriented in a 3D way to give Bragg reflections instead of Debye rings.

The broader peaks correspond to the AgCl crystals, all of which are highly oriented in a 3D way to give Bragg reflections instead of Debye rings.

metadata.title: Growth of Nanocrystals in a Single Crystal of Different Materials: A Way of Giving Function to Molecular Crystals
